{"uri": "8113892730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:41:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:41:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:40:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/vladimir-putin-nuclear-weapons-drills-tests-threats-west-ukraine-war-russia-2535944-2024-05-06", "title": "Vladimir Putin orders tactical nuke drills to counter West's 'threats'", "body": "Russia said on Monday it would practise the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise after what Moscow said were threats from France, the UK and the US.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the US says it has to take seriously, though US officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the US and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the US are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and the UK.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the US unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nUS President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons, but CNN reported that top US officials had done contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the US Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the US-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the US was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to\n\nthe Federation of American Scientists\n\n, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nhas in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that\n\nUkraine had a right\n\nto use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there. {"uri": "8114118861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:15:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:15:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:15:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/05/06/breaking-news/putin-orders-tactical-nuclear-weapon-drills-to-deter-the-west/", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapon drills to deter the West | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin chairs a meeting on economic issues via video link at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, on May 3.\n\nMOSCOW >> Russia said on Monday it would practice the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise after what Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the United States.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks -- warnings which the United States says it has to take seriously though U.S. officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defense ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practice the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defense ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nNUCLEAR RISKS\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nThe defense ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that\n\nUkraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension -- it is unprecedented, and of course, it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nWAR GAMES\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", Obviously, we'll continue to monitor,\" said US Air Force Major General Patrick Ryder, a Pentagon spokesperson.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nUS President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top US officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the US Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the US-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. {"uri": "2024-05-346825452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:12:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:12:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:39:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.aol.com/russia-says-deploying-tactical-nukes-152522210.html", "title": "Russia says it's deploying tactical nukes in drills as Ukraine cries 'blackmail'", "body": "Russia says it's deploying tactical nukes in drills as Ukraine cries 'blackmail'Guy FaulconbridgeUpdated May 6, 2024 at 10:39 AM\n\nMOSCOW - Vladimir Putin's Russia said Monday it would practice deploying tactical nuclear weapons during a military exercise after what Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the U.S.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, it has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the U.S. says it has to take seriously though American officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nMore: Alexei Navalny, a thorn in Vladimir Putin's side, died. What does it mean for Russia?\n\nNuke drills near Ukraine\n\nRussia's defense ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the deployment of tactical nukes. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practice the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District - which borders Ukraine - aviation units and the navy will take part, the defense ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation,\" it said.\n\nMore: Donald Trump threatens NATO, says he would 'encourage' Russia to 'do whatever the hell they want'\n\nUS, Russia lead in warheads\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nMore: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy rebuffs Donald Trump, says he can't 'manage' war with Russia\n\nBiden plays down Russian nuclear threat\n\nPresident Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nThe Kremlin said it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nMore: NATO troops in Ukraine? French proposal brings a warning from Russia\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nPutin casts the Ukraine war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which, he says, humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Russia {"uri": "8113768927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:23:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:23:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:18:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/putin-orders-tactical-nuclear-weapon-drills-to-deter-the-west/77018664", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapon drills to deter the West", "body": "MOSCOW (Reuters) -Russia said on Monday it would practise the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise after what the Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the United States.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the United States says it has to take seriously though U.S. officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nNUCLEAR RISKS\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nWAR GAMES\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8113868350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:24:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:24:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:24:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2465409/putin-orders-tactical-nuclear-weapon-drills-to-deter-the-west", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapon drills to deter the West", "body": "Russia says the US and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of fight between nuclear powers\n\nRussia said on Monday it would practise the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise after what the Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the United States.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the United States says it has to take seriously though U.S. officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nRead: Russia's Medvedev warns of nuclear response if Ukraine hits missile launch sites\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nNuclear risks\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning, opens new tab for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nRead: Putin warns the West a Russia-NATO conflict is just one step from World War Three\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nWar games\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8114877485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "05:14:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T05:14:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T05:14:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/tactical-nuclear-weapons-russia-drills-vladimir-putin-13767902.html", "title": "What are tactical nuclear weapons that Russia plans to use in its drills?", "body": "A Yars intercontinental ballistic missile being launched from an air field during military drills in Russia. According to a statement from the Defence Ministry, the exercises are in response to \"provocative statements and threats of certain Western officials regarding the Russian Federation.\" File image/AP\n\nDays after the Kremlin reacted angrily to remarks made by senior Western officials regarding the war in Ukraine, the Defence Ministry of Russia announced on Monday that it would be holding drills, with the use of tactical nuclear weapons.\n\nAccording to a statement from the Defence Ministry, the exercises are in response to \"provocative statements and threats of certain Western officials regarding the Russian Federation.\"\n\nDespite the fact that its strategic nuclear forces conduct regular exercises, it was the first time Russia had publicly announced drills involving tactical nuclear weapons.\n\nHere's a look at tactical nuclear weapons and their role in the Kremlin's political messaging.\n\nWhat are tactical nuclear weapons?\n\nUnlike nuclear-tipped intercontinental ballistic missiles that can destroy entire cities, tactical nuclear weapons for use against troops on the battlefield are less powerful and can have a yield as small as about one kiloton. The US bomb dropped on Hiroshima during World War II was 15 kilotons.\n\nSuch battlefield nuclear weapons -- aerial bombs, warheads for short-range missiles or artillery munitions -- can be very compact. Their small size allows them to be discreetly carried on a truck or plane.\n\nUnlike strategic weapons, which have been subject to arms control agreements between Moscow and Washington, tactical weapons never have been limited by any such pacts, and Russia hasn't released their numbers or any other specifics related to them.\n\nWhat has Vladimir Putin said about nuclear weapons?\n\nSince launching the full-scale invasion of Ukraine on 24 February, 2022, Russian president Vladimir Putin has repeatedly reminded Western nations about Moscow's nuclear might in a bid to discourage them from increasing military support to Kyiv.\n\nEarly on in the war, Putin frequently referenced Moscow's nuclear arsenal by vowing repeatedly to use \"all means\" necessary to protect Russia. But he later toned down his statements as Ukraine's offensive last summer failed to reach its goals and Russia scored more gains on the battlefield.\n\nMoscow's defence doctrine envisages a nuclear response to an atomic strike or even an attack with conventional weapons that \"threaten the very existence of the Russian state.\" That vague wording has led some pro-Kremlin Russian experts to urge Putin to sharpen it to force the West to take the warnings more seriously.\n\nPutin said last fall that he sees no reason for such a change.\n\n\"There is no situation in which anything would threaten Russian statehood and the existence of the Russian state,\" he said. \"I think that no person of sober mind and clear memory could have an idea to use nuclear weapons against Russia.\"\n\nWhy did Russia ship Belarus nuclear weapons?\n\nLast year, Russia moved some of its tactical nuclear weapons into the territory of Belarus , an ally that neighbours Ukraine and NATO members Poland, Latvia and Lithuania.\n\nBelarus' authoritarian president, Alexander Lukashenko , had long urged Moscow to station nuclear weapons in his country, which has close military ties with Russia and served as a staging ground for the war in Ukraine.\n\nBoth Putin and Lukashenko said that nuclear weapons deployment to Belarus was intended to counter perceived Western threats. Last year, Putin specifically linked the move to the UK government's decision to provide Ukraine with armour-piercing shells containing depleted uranium.\n\nNeither leader said how many were moved -- only that Soviet-era facilities in the country were readied to accommodate them, and that Belarusian pilots and missile crews were trained to use them. The weapons have remained under Russian military control.\n\nThe deployment of tactical nuclear weapons to Belarus, which has a 1,084-kilometre (673-mile) border with Ukraine, would allow Russian aircraft and missiles to reach potential targets there more easily and quickly, if Moscow decides to use them. It has also extended Russia's capability to target several NATO allies in Eastern and Central Europe.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], A day later, UK Foreign Secretary David Cameron said Ukraine could use British weapons against targets inside Russia if it wanted.\n\nRussian officials condemned both statements and warned Moscow would retaliate to what they called a \"dangerous escalation trend\". Moscow has long warned that conflict with NATO would become inevitable if European members of the military alliance sent in their soldiers to fight in Ukraine.\n\nRelations between Western countries, led by the United States, and Russia broke down after Russian forces invaded neighbouring Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nSince the war began, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the US says it has to take seriously though its officials note they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia and the US are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. {"uri": "8113699851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:34:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:34:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:34:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/putin-orders-tactical-nuclear-weapon-drills-to-deter-the-west/article_b2b75e3d-f0c2-51bd-8c39-2303f7f706a1.html", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapon drills to deter the West", "body": "By Guy Faulconbridge\n\nMOSCOW (Reuters) -Russia said on Monday it would practise the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise after what the Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the United States.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks - warnings which the United States says it has to take seriously though U.S. officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the United States and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the preparation and deployment for use of non-strategic nuclear weapons. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nNUCLEAR RISKS\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nWAR GAMES\n\nNATO, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. NATO has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by NATO in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of NATO personnel there.\n\n(Editing by Nick Macfie)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8114331869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:13:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:13:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:13:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2929718-russia-warns-britain-plans-nuclear-drills-amid-western-role-in-ukraine", "title": "Russia Warns Britain, Plans Nuclear Drills Amid Western Role in Ukraine | Law-Order", "body": "Russia threatens to strike British military facilities over concerns about UK involvement in Ukraine. The threats come amid nuclear drills simulated by Russia. The drills involve tactical nuclear weapons, including air bombs and short-range missiles. The Russian Foreign Ministry has summoned British and French ambassadors, warning of consequences. Western officials express alarm over nuclear risks, urging caution and avoiding actions that could lead to escalation. Germany recalls its ambassador for consultations after a suspected cyberattack. Ukrainian forces use drones to strike vehicles in Russia's Belgorod region. Russia intensifies its bombardment of Ukraine's power grid, with a drone attack targeting infrastructure in Sumy.\n\nRussia on Monday threatened to strike British military facilities and said it would hold drills simulating the use of battlefield nuclear weapons amid sharply rising tensions over comments by senior Western officials about possibly deeper involvement in the war in Ukraine.\n\nAfter summoning the British ambassador to the Foreign Ministry, Moscow warned that Ukrainian strikes on Russian territory with UK-supplied weapons could bring retaliatory strikes on British military facilities and equipment on Ukrainian soil or elsewhere.\n\nThe remarks came on the eve of Russian President Vladimir Putin's inauguration to a fifth term in office and in a week when Moscow on Thursday will celebrate Victory Day, its most important secular holiday, marking its defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II.\n\nThe drills are a response to \"provocative statements and threats of certain Western officials regarding the Russian Federation,\" the Defense Ministry said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first time Russia has publicly announced drills involving tactical nuclear weapons, although its strategic nuclear forces regularly hold exercises. Tactical nuclear weapons include air bombs, warheads for short-range missiles and artillery munitions and are meant for use on a battlefield. They are less powerful than the strategic weapons -- massive warheads that arm intercontinental ballistic missiles and are intended to obliterate entire cities.\n\nU.N. spokesman Stephane Dujarric expressed concern that various parties have been talking about issues regarding nuclear weapons more and more recently.\n\n\"Current nuclear risks are at an alarmingly high level,\" Dujarric said. \"All actions that could lead to miscalculation, escalation with catastrophic consequences, must be avoided.\" The Russian announcement was a warning to Ukraine's Western allies about becoming more deeply engaged in the 2-year-old war, where the Kremlin's forces have gained an upper hand amid Ukraine's shortage of manpower and weapons. Some of Ukraine's Western partners have previously expressed concern that the conflict could spill beyond Ukraine into a war between NATO and Russia.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron repeated last week that he doesn't exclude sending troops to Ukraine, and U.K. Foreign Secretary David Cameron said Kyiv's forces will be able to use British long-range weapons to strike targets inside Russia. Some other NATO countries providing weapons to Kyiv have balked at that possibility.\n\nThe Kremlin branded those comments as dangerous, heightening tension between Russia and NATO. The war already has placed significant strain on relations between Moscow and the West.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Monday that Macron's recent statement and other remarks by British and U.S. officials had prompted the nuclear drills.\n\n\"It's a new round of escalation,\" Peskov said, referring to what the Kremlin regarded as provocative statements. \"It's unprecedented and requires special attention and special measures.\" Russia's Foreign Ministry summoned both the French and British ambassadors. It urged the British ambassador \"to think about the inevitable catastrophic consequences of such hostile steps from London.'' Sweden's Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m said the nuclear exercises \"contribute to increasing instability.\" \"In the current security situation, Russia's actions may be considered particularly irresponsible and reckless,\" Billstr\u00f6m told Swedish news agency TT.\n\nDmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council that's chaired by Putin, said in his typically hawkish fashion that the comments by Macron and Cameron risked pushing the nuclear-armed world toward a \"global catastrophe.\" It wasn't the first time Europe's military support for Ukraine has prompted nuclear saber-rattling. In March 2023, after the U.K.'s decision to provide Ukraine with armor-piercing shells containing depleted uranium, Putin said he intends to deploy tactical nuclear weapons on the territory of Ukraine neighbor Belarus.\n\nThe ministry said the exercise is intended to \"increase the readiness of non-strategic nuclear forces to fulfill combat tasks\" and will be held on Putin's orders. The maneuvers will involve missile units of the Southern Military District along with the air force and the navy, it said.\n\nThe Russian announcement stirred little reaction in Ukraine, where the spokesman for the Military Intelligence agency, Andrii Yusov, said on national television: \"Nuclear blackmail is a usual practice of Putin's regime; it does not constitute major news.\" Western officials have blamed Russia for threatening a wider war through provocative acts. NATO countries said last week they are deeply concerned by a campaign of hybrid activities on the military alliance's soil, accusing Moscow of being behind them and saying they represent a security threat.\n\nPeskov dismissed those claims as \"new, unfounded accusations leveled at our country.\" Germany said Monday it recalled its ambassador to Russia for a week of consultations in Berlin following an alleged computer hack of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's party. Meanwhile, Ukrainian drones hit two vehicles Monday in Russia's Belgorod region, killing six people and injuring 35 others, including two children, local authorities said. The area has been hit by Kyiv's forces in recent months.\n\nOne of the vehicles was a minibus carrying farm workers, Belgorod Gov. Vyacheslav Gladkov said.\n\nIt was not possible to independently confirm the report.\n\nWhile Ukraine's army is largely pinned down on the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line due to a shortage of troops and ammunition after more than two years of fighting, it has used its long-range firepower to hit targets deep inside Russia. In what has largely been a war of attrition, Russia also has relied heavily on long-range missile, artillery and drones to wreak damage on Ukraine.\n\nThe Kremlin's forces kept up their bombardment of Ukraine's power grid, with a nighttime Russian drone attack targeting energy infrastructure in Ukraine's northern region of Sumy. Multiple towns and villages in the region, including Sumy, lost power, regional authorities said.\n\nRussia attacked Ukrainian targets with 13 Shahed drones overnight, 12 of which were intercepted in the Sumy region, Ukraine's air force said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-346800883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:44:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:44:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:41:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.aol.com/putin-orders-tactical-nuclear-weapons-150848831.html", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapons drills in response to Western 'threats'", "body": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapons drills in response to Western 'threats'Anna Chernova and Christian Edwards, CNNMay 6, 2024 at 12:41 PM\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has ordered Russian forces to rehearse deploying tactical nuclear weapons, as part of military drills to respond to what he called \"threats\" by the West.\n\nSince invading Ukraine in 2022, Putin has repeatedly made veiled threats to use tactical nuclear weapons against the West, but Monday marked the first time Russia has publicly announced drills.\n\n\"During the exercises, a set of measures will be carried out to practice the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" Russia's defense ministry said.\n\nNon-strategic, or \"tactical,\" nuclear weapons can be used in battlefield situations, carrying less power than strategic nuclear weapons, which have the potential to level entire cities.\n\nRussia's defense ministry said the drills were ordered after \"provocative statements and threats\" by Western officials against Russia, which Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said had reached \"unprecedented levels.\"\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron last week reaffirmed that he would not rule out sending Western troops to Ukraine, as he warned of the risks Russia poses to European security and other countries near its borders.\n\n\"I'm not ruling anything out, because we are facing someone who is not ruling anything out,\" Macron told The Economist magazine. \"I have a clear strategic objective: Russia cannot win in Ukraine. If Russia wins in Ukraine, there will be no security in Europe. Who can pretend that Russia will stop there?\"\n\nAnd during a visit to Ukraine last week, British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine could use British-supplied weapons to strike targets inside Russia.\n\n\"In terms of what the Ukrainians do, in our view it is their decision about how to use these weapons. They are defending their country. They were illegally invaded by Putin and they must take those steps,\" Cameron told reporters after the United Kingdom pledged continued financial and military support for Ukraine.\n\nThe drills announcement also comes shortly after the United States last month passed a long-delayed aid package for Kyiv, which will allow desperately needed military equipment and ammunition to flow to Ukraine as it tries to shore up its frontlines in the face of a renewed Russian onslaughts.\n\nRussian forces last month made further gains in at least three locations along Ukraine's eastern front, as Moscow tries to press home its manpower and ammunition advantage before the bulk of the US aid arrives in Ukraine.\n\nRussia has tended to raise the nuclear specter when its invasion of Ukraine has hit obstacles or when other countries make new pledges of support for Ukraine. After Ukraine liberated large swathes of its territory in late 2022, Putin conceded that the war is \"going to take a while\" and warned of the \"increasing\" threat of nuclear war.\n\nIn February last year, Putin announced that Russia would suspend participation in the New START treaty, a key nuclear arms reduction agreement with the United States, the last remaining pact that regulates the world's two largest nuclear arsenals. Putin said Russia would not be the first to test nuclear weapons, but would do so in the event of a US test.\n\nAfter Macron said in February that sending Western troops to Ukraine could not be ruled out, Putin warned \"this really threatens a conflict with the use of nuclear weapons, and therefore the destruction of civilization.\"\n\nUS President Joe Biden and State Department officials have previously downplayed concerns that Putin could deploy a nuclear weapon, but continue to take the threats seriously.\n\nIn late 2022, the US began \"preparing rigorously\" for Russia potentially striking Ukraine with a tactical nuclear weapon, in what would have been the first nuclear attack in war since the US dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki nearly 80 years before, two senior administration officials previously told CNN.\n\nIn Monday's announcement, Russia's defense ministry said the military's General Staff had begun preparations for conducting \"exercises in the near future with missile formations of the Southern Military District involving aviation as well as naval forces.\"\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": After Ukraine liberated large swathes of its territory in late 2022, Putin conceded that the war is \"going to take a while\" and warned of the \"increasing\" threat of nuclear war.\n\nIn February last year, Putin announced that Russia would suspend participation in the New START treaty, a key nuclear arms reduction agreement with the United States, the last remaining pact that regulates the world's two largest nuclear arsenals. Putin said Russia would not be the first to test nuclear weapons, but would do so in the event of a US test.\n\nAfter Macron said in February that sending Western troops to Ukraine could not be ruled out, Putin warned \"this really threatens a conflict with the use of nuclear weapons, and therefore the destruction of civilization.\"\n\nUS President Joe Biden and State Department officials have previously downplayed concerns that Putin could deploy a nuclear weapon, but continue to take the threats seriously.\n\nIn response to Russia's latest announcement, the US said it had seen no change in Russia's \"strategic force posture\" following Moscow's announcement that it would begin tactical nuclear weapons drills, according to Pentagon spokesperson Maj. Gen. Patrick Ryder.\n\nRyder said Russia's announcement is \"completely inappropriate,\" and \"an example of the kind of irresponsible rhetoric that we've seen from Russia in the past.\"\n\nIn late 2022, the US began \"preparing rigorously\" for Russia potentially striking Ukraine with a tactical nuclear weapon, in what would have been the first nuclear attack in war since the US dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki nearly 80 years before, two senior administration officials previously told CNN.\n\nIn Monday's announcement, Russia's defense ministry said the military's General Staff had {"uri": "8114075464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:45:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:45:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:45:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1831864", "title": "Putin orders tactical nuclear weapon drills to deter the West", "body": "Russia said on Monday it would practice the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons as part of a military exercise, after what Moscow said were threats from France, Britain and the United States.\n\nSince Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of rising nuclear risks -- warnings which the US says it has to take seriously, though US officials say they have seen no change in Russia's nuclear posture.\n\nRussia says the US and its European allies are pushing the world to the brink of confrontation between nuclear powers by supporting Ukraine with tens of billions of dollars of weapons, some of which are being used against Russian territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it would hold military drills, including practicing the preparation and deployment of non-strategic nuclear weapons. President Vladimir Putin ordered the exercises, the ministry added.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practice the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nIt added that missile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part.\n\nThe exercise aims to ensure Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nRussia and the US are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nUS President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons, but CNN reported that top US officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, although the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\"\n\nThe defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement. The Kremlin said it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the US Senate.\n\nMacron has publicly raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine, while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending Nato soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension -- it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the US-led Nato military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three, but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nNato, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. Nato has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by Nato in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the US was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging Nato and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. Western leaders have vowed to work for a defeat of Russian forces in Ukraine, while ruling out any deployment of Nato personnel there.", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dawn"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@dawn.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Nuclear weapon"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ukraine"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Ukraine"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Russia"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Russia"}}}, {"uri": What does it mean for Russia?\n\nRussia's defense ministry said it would hold military drills including practice for the deployment of tactical nukes. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practice the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District - which borders Ukraine - aviation units and the navy will take part, the defense ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation,\" it said.\n\nMore: Donald Trump threatens NATO, says he would 'encourage' Russia to 'do whatever the hell they want'\n\nRussia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads. China has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\nMore: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy rebuffs Donald Trump, says he can't 'manage' war with Russia\n\nPresident Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top U.S. officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nThe Kremlin said it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the U.S. Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nMore: NATO troops in Ukraine? French proposal brings a warning from Russia\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending NATO soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension - it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nPutin casts the Ukraine war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which, he says, humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging NATO and encroaching on what Moscow considers Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship. It said the exercises were ordered by President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"During the exercise, a set of measures will be carried out to practise the issues of preparation and use of non-strategic nuclear weapons,\" the ministry said.\n\nMissile forces in the Southern Military District, aviation and the navy will take part, the defence ministry said.\n\nThe exercise is aimed at ensuring Russia's territorial integrity and sovereignty \"in response to provocative statements and threats by certain Western officials against the Russian Federation\", it said.\n\nNUCLEAR RISKS\n\nUS President Joe Biden said last year that he felt there was no real prospect of Russia using nuclear weapons but CNN reported that top US officials did contingency planning for a potential Russian nuclear strike against Ukraine in 2022.\n\nSome Western and Ukrainian officials have said Russia is bluffing over nuclear weapons to scare the West, though the Kremlin has repeatedly indicated that it would consider breaking the nuclear taboo if Russia's existence was threatened.\n\nBiggest nuclear powers Russia and the United States are by far the world's biggest nuclear powers, holding more than 10,600 of the world's 12,100 nuclear warheads.\n\nChina has the third-largest nuclear arsenal, followed by France and Britain.\n\nRussia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads, according to the Federation of American Scientists, though there is uncertainty about exact figures for such weapons due to a lack of transparency.\n\nNo power has used nuclear weapons in war since the United States unleashed the first atomic bomb attacks on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMajor nuclear powers routinely check their nuclear weapons but very rarely publicly link such exercises to specific perceived threats in the way that Russia has.\n\n\"We do not see anything new here,\" said Andriy Yusov, a spokesperson for Ukrainian military intelligence. \"Nuclear blackmail is a constant practice of Putin's regime.\" The defence ministry, run by long-term Putin ally Sergei Shoigu, did not say which specific Western officials it was referring to in its statement.\n\nThe Kremlin said that it was in response to remarks by French President Emmanuel Macron, British officials and a representative of the US Senate.\n\nMacron has in public raised the idea of sending European troops to fight Russia in Ukraine while British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by London to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Western statements about sending Nato soldiers to Ukraine amounted to \"a completely new round of escalation of tension -- it is unprecedented, and of course it requires special attention and special measures\".\n\nPutin warned the West in March that a direct conflict between Russia and the US-led Nato military alliance would mean the planet was one step away from World War Three but said hardly anyone wanted such a scenario.\n\nWAR GAMES\n\nNato, created in 1949 to provide collective security against the Soviet Union, is currently holding the \"Steadfast Defender\" exercise, its largest since the end of the Cold War. Nato has not said whether it would include rehearsal of any nuclear element.\n\nA nuclear command exercise by Nato in 1983 prompted fears at the top levels of the Kremlin that the United States was preparing for a surprise nuclear attack.\n\nPutin has faced calls inside Russia from some hardliners to change Russia's nuclear doctrine, which sets out the conditions under which Russia would use a nuclear weapon, though Putin said last year he saw no need for change.\n\nBroadly, the doctrine says such a weapon would be used in response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\nPutin casts the war as part of a centuries-old battle with the West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by enlarging Natp and encroaching on what Moscow considers to be Russia's historical sphere of influence.\n\nUkraine and its Western backers say the war is an imperial-style land grab by a corrupt dictatorship.
